candidates.definition: Standardized measurements for dividing and quantifying time periods

positive_examples: The meeting lasted exactly two hours and thirty minutes.
She finished the race in 4 minutes and 23 seconds.
Please wait one hour before taking your next dose.
He worked for six straight hours without a break.
The presentation is scheduled for 20 minutes.
negative_examples: We met during the morning rush hour.
The golden hour provides perfect lighting for photos.
It happened in the moment when everything changed.
She lived in the Victorian era.
We'll discuss this at the appropriate time.
training_hints.disambiguation: Not to be confused with: TimeOfDay, TimePeriod, Moment, Era

candidates.definition: A standardized unit of time used for organizing dates and scheduling events

positive_examples: The project deadline is next month
We meet every Tuesday during the fall semester
Sales increased significantly in the third quarter
The Jurassic period lasted about 56 million years
I've been working here for over a decade
This week has been particularly busy
negative_examples: The concert starts at 8 PM tonight
It happened in the blink of an eye
training_hints.disambiguation: Not to be confused with: Duration, Moment, TimeOfDay, Deadline, Schedule

candidates.definition: Commonly recognized time periods or moments with established names

positive_examples: We usually have dinner at dinnertime around six o'clock
The sunrise this morning was absolutely beautiful
I prefer working during daytime hours when it's bright
The meeting is scheduled for 10 AM tomorrow
Let's meet for lunch at lunchtime
The sunset painted the sky orange and pink
negative_examples: The meeting will last for two hours
We waited there for a long time
The project deadline is next week
The concert starts in thirty minutes
This occurred during the Renaissance period
training_hints.disambiguation: Not to be confused with: Duration, Frequency, Deadline, TimeSequence
